content: The "Hospital Cooperative Agreement Act" aims to promote collaboration among hospitals to reduce costs and enhance efficiency in healthcare delivery by avoiding unnecessary duplication of expensive medical services. Additionally, a Hospital Technology and Services Sharing Demonstration Program is introduced to facilitate this cooperation. The Secretary will establish a demonstration program awarding up to 10 grants to hospitals for collaboration on expensive medical technology or services. The program aims to reduce costs, improve access to care, and enhance quality of care. Eligible applicants must collaborate with two or more hospitals. The program awards grants to hospitals for collaboration on expensive medical technology or services to reduce costs, improve access to care, and enhance quality. Eligible applicants must be hospitals submitting an application to the Secretary. To be eligible for a grant, a hospital must submit an application to the Secretary, including a desire to cooperate with other hospitals for sharing medical technology or services. The hospital must enter into a cooperative agreement with another hospital for sharing medical technology or services, detailing the activities, considerations, and any other relevant information required by the Secretary. The hospital must enter into a cooperative agreement with another hospital for sharing medical technology or services, detailing activities, considerations, and other information as required by the Secretary. The Administrator of the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research will develop evaluation guidelines for applications submitted under the agreement. The Secretary will evaluate applications in consultation with the Administrator. The Administrator of the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research will develop evaluation guidelines for applications submitted under cooperative agreements. The Secretary will evaluate applications for grants based on guidelines developed by the Administrator of the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research. The antitrust laws include the Federal Trade Commission Act, the Clayton Act, and State antitrust laws. The Clayton Act, also known as the ``Clayton Act'' (38 Stat. 730; chapter 323; 15 U.S.C. 12 et seq.; 18 U.S.C. 402, 660, 3285, 3691; 29 U.S.C. 52, 53), authorizes appropriations for fiscal years 1994 through 1998 to carry out antitrust laws, including State antitrust laws.
